titleStmt.title: Letter from Paddy Guinness to Cesca Chenevix Trench, 6 June 1916
titleStmt.author: Paddy Guinness

availability.p: All rights reserved. No part of this image may be reproduced, distributed, or transmitted in any form or by any means, including photocopying, recording, or other electronic or mechanical methods, without the prior written permission of the institutional or private owner of the image and the Letters of 1916 project. For permission requests, write to the Letters of 1916 at letters1916@gmail.com.

note.p: Letter from Paddy Guinness to Cesca Chenevix Trench (an Anglo-Irish woman who adopted Irish identity and took an Irish name Sadhbh Trinseac). Guinness writes regarding the Irish Volunteers and Irish language.

Cesca Chevenix Trench, illustrator, was an Anglo-Irish member of the Gaelic League who took an Irish identity and changed her name to Sadhbh Trinseach. Her three brothers enlisted with the British Army in 1914 with her closest brother, Reggie (1888-1918), gazetted to the Sherwood Foresters. Trench served in the Stephen's Green garrison during the Rising, later writing that the Rising had been a 'tragic mistake.' Trench later married Diarmuid Coffey on 17 April 1918. Cesca would perish, like so many others, from the virulent Spanish Flu in October 1918.

msIdentifier.idno: Coffey & Chenevix Trench Papers, Collection List 153

application.desc: Letter processing pipeline built by Richard Hadden & Linda Spinazze, Maynooth University, 2015.
LetEd. letter editing tool built by Richard Hadden, Maynooth University, 2015. Built using the Python Flask Framework and the Angles web-based XML editor.

text.body:
Is maith liom go bFuairis amach mo sheóladh — creid mé le buidheachas mór Prionnsias Airmeas. (F.C.Ormsby) this case __________ perhaps you would be good eno' to assure me that the confusion created in my mind by your communication has no real cause. I observe conclude from it that you are unacquainted with the language of this country & of which your name proclaims you in no uncertain voice to be a native. in no uncertain voice. These two seeming contradictory facts force me to the conclusion that I have mistaken the identity of the person I am addressing.
London S.W.
12.15AM 6 Jun 16
Miss Cesca Chenevix Trench Temple Hill Terenure Co: Dublin.
the said window. You shd then face
to the east deploy & advance in extended
order down the incline. Very careful to avoid future
lurching movements I leave to yr own
discretion & and the military strategical know
-ledge you will have acquired
from a study of the front page
of the shrunken National Volun -teer.
4th. The nature of the party
is that known as the small
céilid beag or 'small caylee'
which is used for a generic
term for anything from a
friendly gathering to a ball.
In The circumscribed place at my
disposal precludes the latter
possibility, but I may mention
that a turf fire will be a
feature.
I trust that this explanation will prove satis
-factory to you & in
Perhaps you wd be good enough
to transfer my invitation
to yr namesake together with
the expression of my profound
respect & to pardon the error
into which I have fallen.
In conclusion may I urge upon you
the consideration that as
Mr Diarmuid o Cobhthaigh's
position as Sec: of the National
Volunteers, did not in his
opinion absolve him from
the necessity of sp using
his native language, so your
position doubtless most
creditable, tho' unknown to
me does not absolve you. I am Sir
Your obedient servant Paddy Guinness.
